æ ‡é¢˜ - DARTS: Differentiable Architecture Search

æ‘˜è¦ - This paper addresses the scalability challenge of architecturesearch by formulating the task in a differentiable manner. Unlikeconventional approaches of applying evolution or reinforcement learningover a discrete and non-differentiable search space, our method is basedon the continuous relaxation of the architecture representation,allowing efficient search of the architecture using gradient descent.Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, ImageNet, Penn Treebank andWikiText-2 show that our algorithm excels in discoveringhigh-performance convolutional architectures for image classificationand recurrent architectures for language modeling, while being orders ofmagnitude faster than state-of-the-art non-differentiable techniques.Our implementation has been made publicly available to facilitatefurther research on efficient architecture search algorithms.

[!Note] An overview of DARTS (a)Operations on the edges are initially unknown.

  1. Continuous relaxation of the search space by placing a mixture ofcandidate operations on each edge.

  2. Joint optimization of the mixing probabilities and the networkweights by solving a bilevel optimization problem.

  3. Inducing the final architecture from the learned mixingprobabilities.

1.5.1 Search Space

Searching for a computation cell as the buildingblock of the final architecture.

  1. A cell is a directed acyclic graph consisting of anordered sequence of N nodes.
  2. Each node: latent representation
    • "Latent representation" refers to a representation form used inmachine learning and deep learning to represent hidden features orabstract representations of data.
  3. Each directed edge: operation
  4. Each intermediate node is computed based on all of its predecessors:\[x^{(j)}=\sum_{i<j} o^{(i,j)}\left(x^{(i)} ight)\]
  5. A special zero operation is also included to indicate a lack ofconnection between two nodes.
  6. learning the cell \( ightarrow\)learning the operations on its edges.

1.5.2 ContinuousRelaxation And Optimization

  1. Relaxation: Relax the categorical choice of aparticular operation to a softmax over all possible operations: \[ ar{o}^{(i, j)}(x)=\sum_{o \in \mathcal{O}} rac{\exp \left(\alpha_o^{(i, j)} ight)}{\sum_{o^{\prime} \in\mathcal{O}} \exp \left(\alpha_{o^{\prime}}^{(i, j)} ight)}o(x)\]
    • \(\alpha_(i, j)\): the operationmixing weights for a pair of nodes \((i,j)\)
    • learning a set of continuous variables \(Î±= \{Î±(i, j)\}\)
  2. [[Bilevel optimization]]: After relaxation, ourgoal is to jointly learn the architecture \(\alpha\) and the weights \(w\) within all the mixed operations \[ egin{array}{cl}\min _\alpha &\mathcal{L}_{ ext {val }}\left(w^*(\alpha), \alpha ight) \ ext {s.t. } & w^*(\alpha)=\operatorname{argmin}_w \mathcal{L}_{ ext{train }}(w, \alpha)\end{array}\]
    • optimize the validation loss, but using gradient descent.
    • the architecture \(\alpha\) couldbe viewed as a special type of hyper-parameter

1.5.3 ApproximateArchitecture Gradient

  1. One-step Approximation: ï¼ˆAlso can be seen inNesterovï¼ŒMAMLï¼‰Evaluating the architecture gradient exactly can beprohibitive due to the expensive inner optimization. \[ egin{aligned} & abla_\alpha\mathcal{L}_{ ext {val }}\left(w^*(\alpha), \alpha ight) \ \approx& abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}_{ ext {val }}\left(w-\xi abla_w\mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha),\alpha ight)\end{aligned}\]
    • \(\xi\) helps to converge to abetter local optimum
  2. Chain rule:
    1. Let: \[ egin{align*}w^\prime=f(w,\alpha) &= w - \xi abla_w \mathcal{L}_{ ext{train}}(w, \alpha)\g(w, \alpha) &= \mathcal{L}_{ ext{val}}(f(w, \alpha),\alpha)\end{align*}\]
    2. So: \[ egin{align*} abla_\alpha\mathcal{L}_{ ext{val}}\left(w-\xi abla_w\mathcal{L}_{ ext{train}}(w, \alpha), \alpha ight) &= rac{\partial g}{\partial \alpha} + rac{dg}{d\alpha}\&= rac{\partial g}{\partial f} \cdot rac{\partial f}{\partial \alpha} + rac{dg}{d\alpha}\&= rac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{ ext{val}}}{\partial f} \cdot rac{\partial}{\partial\alpha} (w - \xi abla_w \mathcal{L}_{ ext{train}}(w, \alpha)) + rac{d\mathcal{L}_ ext{val}}{d\alpha}\end{align*}\]
    3. Where: \[ rac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{ ext{val}}}{\partial f} = abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}_{v al}\left(w, \alpha ight)\]
    4. And: \[ rac{\partial}{\partial \alpha}(w - \xi abla_w \mathcal{L}_{ ext{train}}(w, \alpha)) = -\xi abla_{\alpha, w}^2 \mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}(w,\alpha)\]
    5. And: \[ rac{dg}{d\alpha} = abla_\alpha\mathcal{L}_{v a l}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight)\]
    6. So: \[ abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}_{ ext{val }}\left(w-\xi abla_w \mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha),\alpha ight)= abla_\alpha \mathcal{L}_{ ext {val }}\left(w^{\prime},\alpha ight)-\xi abla_{\alpha, w}^2 \mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}(w,\alpha) abla_{w^{\prime}} \mathcal{L}_{ ext {val }}\left(w^{\prime},\alpha ight)\]
  3. Finite difference approximationï¼šThe expressionabove contains an expensive matrix-vector product in its second term.\[ abla_{\alpha, w}^2 \mathcal{L}_{ ext{train }}(w, \alpha) abla_{w^{\prime}} \mathcal{L}_{ ext {val}}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight) \approx rac{ abla_\alpha\mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}\left(w^{+}, \alpha ight)- abla_\alpha\mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}\left(w^{-}, \alpha ight)}{2\epsilon}\]
    • Central difference: \(f^{\prime}(x)\approx rac{f(x+h)-f(x-h)}{2 h}\)
    • Taylor Formula:
      1. We have: \(f(x)= rac{f\left(x_0 ight)}{0!}+ rac{f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight)}{1!}\left(x-x_0 ight)+\ldots\)
      2. Then: \(f\left(x_0+h ight)=f\left(x_0 ight)+ rac{f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight)}{1!} h+\ldots\)
      3. Replace \(h\) with \(hA\): \( egin{aligned} &f\left(x_0+hA ight)=f\left(x_0 ight)+ rac{f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight)}{1!} h A+\ldots \ &f\left(x_0-hA ight)=f\left(x_0 ight)- rac{f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight)}{1 !}hA+\ldots\end{aligned}\)
      4. Subtract one equation from another: \(f^{\prime}\left(x_0 ight) \cdot A \approx rac{f\left(x_0+h A ight)-f\left(x_0-h A ight)}{2 h}\)
    • Where:
      1. \(f^\prime(x_0)= abla_{\alpha, w}^2\mathcal{L}_{ ext {train }}(w, \alpha)\)
      2. \(A= abla_{w^{\prime}} \mathcal{L}_{ ext{val }}\left(w^{\prime}, \alpha ight)\)
      3. \(h=\epsilon\)
      4. \(w^{ \pm}=w \pm \epsilon abla_{w^{\prime}} \mathcal{L}_{v a l}\left(w^{\prime},\alpha ight)\)
  4. First-order Approximation: \(\xi=0\), the second-order derivative willdisappear.

1.5.4 Deriving DiscreteArchitectures

  1. The strength of an operation is defined as \( rac{\exp \left(\alpha_o^{(i,j)} ight)}{\sum_{o^{\prime} \in \mathcal{O}} \exp\left(\alpha_{o^{\prime}}^{(i, j)} ight)}\).
  2. Discretization: At the end of search, a discretearchitecture can be obtained by replacing each mixed operation with themost likely operation \[o^{(i,j)}=\operatorname{argmax}_{o \in \mathcal{O}} \alpha_o^{(i,j)}\]
  3. Retain the top-k strongest operations.
